description: From Middle English revewe, reveue, from Old French reveüe, revue (Modern French: revue), feminine form of reveü, past participle of reveoir (French: revoir), from Latin revideō, from re- +videō (“see, observe”) (English: video). Equivalent to re- +‎ view. Compare retrospect. Doublet of revue.

entries.meaning: A second or subsequent reading of a text or artifact in an attempt to gain new insights.
examples: I need to make a review of the book before I can understand it.

entries.meaning: An account intended as a critical evaluation of a text or a piece of work.
examples: The newspaper review was full of praise for the play.

entries.meaning: (law) A judicial reassessment of a case or an event.
examples: The victims demanded a full judicial review of the case.

entries.meaning: A stage show made up of topical sketches etc.
examples: The Cambridge Footlights Review launched many Monty Python faces.

entries.meaning: A survey of the available items or material.
examples: The magazine contained a review of Paris restaurants.

entries.meaning: A periodical which makes a survey of the arts or some other field.
examples: The Times Literary Review is published in London.

entries.meaning: A military inspection or display for the benefit of superiors or VIPs.
examples: The troops assembled for a review by the Queen.

entries.meaning: A forensic inspection to assess compliance with regulations or some code.
examples: The regulators demanded a review against NYSE practices.

verbs.description: review (third-person singular simple present reviews, present participle reviewing, simple past and past participle reviewed)

entries.meaning: To survey; to look broadly over.
examples: Before I tackle the question directly, I must briefly review historical approaches to the problem.

entries.meaning: To write a critical evaluation of a new art work etc.; to write a review.
examples: The critic reviews every new play in London.

entries.meaning: To look back over in order to correct or edit; to revise.
(transitive, US, Canada) To look over again (something previously written or learned), especially in preparation for an examination.
(obsolete) To view or see again; to look back on.
(obsolete) To retrace; to go over again.
